name: CCSD(T)
brief: Coupled cluster with singles, doubles, and perturbative triples; gold standard for single-reference correlation.
long_description: CCSD(T) treats correlation via exponential cluster operator exp(T1+T2+T3) where T1 (singles) and T2 (doubles) are solved iteratively and T3 (triples) are added perturbatively. Size-extensive, accurate (~1 kcal/mol for well-behaved systems), but scales as O(N⁷) with system size.
strengths: Gold standard accuracy for single-reference systems; size-extensive; systematically improvable.
limitations: Very expensive for large systems; single-reference only; poor for multi-reference problems.
typical_use_cases: Benchmark calculations, thermochemistry, spectroscopy of small-medium molecules.

name: B3LYP
brief: Hybrid DFT functional with 20% exact exchange; widely-used general-purpose functional.
long_description: B3LYP is a hybrid functional combining Becke's 1988 exchange, Lee-Yang-Parr correlation, and 20% Hartree-Fock exact exchange. Popular for organic/bio molecules due to good accuracy/cost balance. Known weaknesses: self-interaction error, poor dispersion, underestimated barriers.
strengths: Good accuracy for organic molecules; efficient; derivative properties available; widely benchmarked.
limitations: Dispersion missing (needs correction); self-interaction error; poor for transition metal complexes; underestimates barriers.
typical_use_cases: Organic chemistry, structure optimization, frequencies, routine molecular properties.

name: MP2
brief: Second-order Møller-Plesset perturbation theory; efficient post-HF correlation method.
long_description: MP2 treats electron correlation to second order in perturbation theory with HF as reference. Includes dynamic correlation via double excitations. Scales as O(N⁵), making it tractable for larger systems. Not size-extensive at finite order but often sufficient accuracy.
strengths: Efficient post-HF method; captures dynamic correlation; reasonable accuracy for non-covalent interactions.
limitations: Not size-extensive; poor for multi-reference; can fail for challenging systems (e.g., ozone).
typical_use_cases: Medium-large molecules, non-covalent interactions, geometry optimization, frequency calculations.

name: CASSCF
brief: Complete active space self-consistent field; multi-reference method for static correlation.
long_description: CASSCF divides orbitals into active (full CI), inactive (doubly occupied), and virtual spaces. Captures static correlation and near-degeneracies. Active space choice is critical. Often followed by CASPT2 or MRCI for dynamic correlation.
strengths: Handles multi-reference character; captures static correlation; qualitatively correct for bond breaking.
limitations: Active space choice requires expertise; expensive for large active spaces; lacks dynamic correlation (needs CASPT2).
typical_use_cases: Bond breaking, excited states, transition metal complexes, diradicals.

name: Hartree-Fock
brief: Self-consistent field method using single determinant; foundation for post-HF methods.
long_description: Hartree-Fock is the starting point for many quantum chemistry methods. Variationally optimizes molecular orbitals in mean-field approximation. Neglects electron correlation. Scales as O(N⁴) for canonical HF.
strengths: Variational; size-consistent; foundation for post-HF; interpretable MOs.
limitations: No correlation; poor energetics; fails for multi-reference systems.
typical_use_cases: Starting point for post-HF, qualitative MO analysis, initial guess for SCF.

name: PBE
brief: Generalized gradient approximation (GGA) functional; parameter-free, robust for solids.
long_description: Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) is a GGA functional derived from first principles without empirical parameters. Improved over LDA for molecular systems. Widely used in solid-state physics. No exact exchange (pure GGA).
strengths: Parameter-free; robust; good for solids; thermochemistry reasonable.
limitations: No exact exchange; self-interaction error; poor dispersion; underestimates bandgaps.
typical_use_cases: Solid-state calculations, surfaces, thermochemistry, materials science.

name: TD-DFT
brief: Time-dependent density functional theory; excited state method using linear response.
long_description: TD-DFT applies linear response theory to ground-state DFT to compute excited states. Solves eigenvalue problem for excitation energies and oscillator strengths. Functional choice critical. Known issues: charge-transfer excitations, Rydberg states.
strengths: Efficient excited state method; good for valence excitations; oscillator strengths.
limitations: Charge-transfer failures; functional dependence; double excitations missing.

name: EOM-CCSD
brief: Equation-of-motion coupled cluster for excited states; accurate multi-state method.
long_description: EOM-CCSD applies equation-of-motion formalism to coupled cluster theory. Simultaneously treats ground and excited states. Accurate for valence excitations, charge-transfer states. Scales as O(N⁶) for canonical implementation.
strengths: Balanced description of ground and excited states; good for charge-transfer; systematically improvable.
limitations: Expensive for large systems; single-reference based; poor for double excitations.

name: CASPT2
brief: Complete active space second-order perturbation theory; multi-reference method for excited states.
long_description: CASPT2 adds dynamic correlation to CASSCF via second-order perturbation theory. Handles multi-reference character and excited states. Choice of IPEA shift and level shift affects results. Expensive but accurate.
strengths: Multi-reference; handles near-degeneracies; good for complex excited states.
limitations: Active space choice critical; expensive; intruder state problems; IPEA/level shift dependence.
typical_use_cases: Transition metal complexes, photochemistry, conical intersections.

name: ADC(2)
brief: Algebraic diagrammatic construction to second order; efficient excited state method.
long_description: ADC(2) is a Hermitian excited state method based on Green's function theory. Scales as O(N⁵), more efficient than EOM-CCSD. Good for valence excitations. Extended variants (ADC(2)-x, ADC(3)) available.
strengths: Efficient; size-consistent; good for valence states; Hermitian formulation.
limitations: Underestimates charge-transfer; not as accurate as EOM-CCSD for difficult cases.
typical_use_cases: Large molecules, UV-Vis spectra, screening studies.

name: SAC-CI
brief: Symmetry-adapted cluster configuration interaction; size-extensive excited state method.
long_description: SAC-CI uses symmetry-adapted cluster expansion for excited states. Size-extensive by design. Good balance of accuracy and cost. Handles valence and Rydberg states well.
strengths: Size-extensive; good for Rydberg states; symmetry exploitation.
limitations: Less common than EOM-CCSD or TD-DFT; fewer implementations.
